name: philodendron-bipinnatifidum
country-or-region-of-origin: E. Bolivia to SE. & S. Brazil and NE. Argentina
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Fruits are a berry that is white to orange or red in color.
flower-description: Seasonal bloomer with white flowers with no petals arise on a spadix that is enclosed with a red-purple spathe. Flowers are unusual on indoor plants. Spadix is shorter than or equal to the spathe. The spathe forms a tube around the spadix and expands above the spadix to a hood. They are greenish-yellow in color. It can take 10-15 years for a plant to bloom indoors.
leaf-description: The glossy, leathery leaves are shiny, dark green, simple, large, deeply lobed, and attached to long, smooth petioles. They can be up to 4 feet long. Margins are wavy or entire. Stipules are large, free, and lanceolate.
stem-description: Stems are stout, green, and have prominent leaf scars and adventitious roots.
poison-symptoms: If ingested, oral irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue, and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting (not horses), and difficulty swallowing. The sap can cause skin irritation.
